page.title: 09ANIMALS OF BEWCASTLE
page.content: In addition to the domestic animals kept on the many farms, the area is rich in wild animals. These range in size downwards from the roe deer to common fieldmice and shrews.The roe deer live in the natural woodland to be found bordering the rivers and in the planted coniferous forests, but they can frequently be seen crossing roads , especially in the evening or early in the morning.Limited numbers are culled by the Forestry Game Warden to limit the amount of damage caused to young trees.Next in size is the fox, of which one or two inhabit this area causing losses to the farmers of poultry .Rabbits and hares are common , and some say, increasing in numbers.Hares live above ground making nests in long grass or rushes , rabbits have burrows in the dykes (local name for field boundary).
